docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: PART 4 THE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 165–176]

heading.title: PART 4 THE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 165–176]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 4 THE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 165–176]

leg:heading.title: THE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 165–176]

p.text: [Pt 4 am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 4]
In this Part—
[def rep Act 210 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1]

means an Act (other than this Act) enacted before the commencement of this Act, or a rule, by-law, regulation or ordinance, or any other instrument or document whatsoever, of the same or a different kind or nature, made, proclaimed, issued or published before the commencement of this Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 166] s 166 Criminal jurisdiction of the Court

p.text: The Court has the criminal jurisdiction conferred or imposed on it by or under this Act, the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 or any other Act.

The Court has generally the same criminal jurisdiction as each Court of Quarter Sessions had immediately before the commencement of this Act, except as regards any offences prescribed for the purposes of section 46 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986.
[subs (2) am Act 94 of 1999 s 6 and Sch 4 ; Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003]
[s 166 subst Act 210 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1]
Previously the District Courts had no criminal jurisdiction, but the judges in their capacity as chairmen of Quarter Sessions exercised an extensive criminal jurisdiction.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 166.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Appeal Act 1912.

Care must be taken with respect to appeals from a judge exercising the criminal jurisdiction as unless there is a stated right of appeal in the relevant Act, for example, the Criminal Appeal Act 1912 , there may be no available appeal: see Grzybowicz v Smiljanic [1980] 1 NSWLR 627 and Maric v R [1981] 2 NSWLR 100 (bail).

Care must also be taken as to the power of a judge to commit for contempt when exercising the criminal jurisdiction: see Attorney-General (NSW) v Davis (NSWCA, Moffit P, Hope and Hutley JJA, 23 July 1980, unreported).
Legislation cited in [DCA s 166.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 section.

In the exercise of its criminal jurisdiction the court does not have the power to award costs unless such jurisdiction is expressly provided for by statute: Director of Public Prosecutions v Deeks (1994) 34 NSWLR 523 . As to the limited extent of any implied power which arises from the jurisdiction conferred by the section see John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v District Court of New South Wales (2004) 61 NSWLR 344; 50 ACSR 380; [2004] NSWCA 324; BC200406122 .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 166.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 166.
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 Div 2.

It seems DCA s 166 does not in terms confer powers to issue a subpoena. The power of a registrar of the District Court to issue a subpoena in relation to a criminal trial, subject to any statutory constraints, is conferred by DCR Pt 53, Div 2 : KS v Veitch [2012] NSWCCA 186; BC201206760 at [13]–[14] (subpoena issued pre-arraignment for hospital medical records).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 167] s 167 Abolition of Courts of Quarter Sessions

leg:heading.title: Abolition of Courts of Quarter Sessions

p.text: Courts of Quarter Sessions are abolished.
[s 167 am Act 1 of 1975 s 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 168] s 168 References to Courts of Quarter Sessions

leg:heading.title: References to Courts of Quarter Sessions

p.text: A reference in any instrument to a Court of Quarter Sessions shall, in relation to the exercise of that Court's criminal jurisdiction, be construed as a reference to the District Court in its criminal jurisdiction.
[s 168 subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 4]

A Judge exercising the criminal jurisdiction of the Court has, in relation to proceedings in the Court in that jurisdiction, the same powers, authorities, duties and functions as a Chairman of Quarter Sessions would have had, in relation to the like proceedings in a Court of Quarter Sessions, had this Act not been enacted.
[subs (1) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 4]
Except where express provision to the contrary is made by any other Act—
the trial of all issues arising in the Court in the exercise of its criminal jurisdiction;
the hearing of any application, or the making of any order, in relation to any such issues; and
all other matters relating to the exercise of that jurisdiction;
shall be held before or dealt with by a Judge sitting alone.
[subs (2) subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 4]

A reference in any instrument to a Chairman of Quarter Sessions shall, in relation to a Court of Quarter Sessions in its criminal jurisdiction, be construed as a reference to a Judge exercising the criminal jurisdiction of the District Court.
[subs (3) subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 4]
[s 170 rep Act 210 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1]

The Rule Committee may make rules, not inconsistent with this Act or any other Act, for or with respect to any matter that by this Act is required or permitted to be prescribed for the purposes of, or in connection with, the exercise by the Court of its criminal jurisdiction or that is necessary or convenient to be prescribed for carrying out or giving effect to this Part and Division 3 of Part II or any Act under or by virtue of which rules under this Part apply, and in particular for or with respect to providing for the procedure and practice to be followed in the Court in all proceedings in which, and with respect to which, the Court has for the time being criminal jurisdiction and regulating or providing for any matters incidental to, or relating to, any such procedure or practice.
Without limiting the generality of subsection (1) , rules may be made under that subsection for or with respect to any of the following—

prescribing the duties and functions of the Judicial Registrar, other registrars and other officers of the Court and the records to be kept by them in relation to or for the purposes of any proceedings;
conferring on a registrar in particular proceedings power, subject to the rules, to issue on behalf of a defendant or an appellant in those proceedings—
a subpoena requiring a person specified in the subpoena to attend and give evidence in the proceedings; or

a subpoena requiring a person specified in the subpoena to attend and produce, for the purpose of evidence, in the proceedings any document or thing that is in the possession or under the control of that person;
providing for the sittings of the Court and the regulation of business at those sittings;

prescribing and providing for the places at which particular proceedings may be held and, subject to any enactment or rule of law which confers powers on the Attorney General with respect to the venue or changes of venue of proceedings providing for the venue of proceedings to be changed and prescribing the circumstances in which, and the conditions subject to which, any such change may be made;
providing for the vacations and holidays of the Court and the hearing and disposal of proceedings during any such vacations or holidays;
providing for all procedural matters relating to or incidental to the indictment and arraignment of an accused person, including motions to quash or stay indictments;
providing for all matters relating to the conduct of proceedings, including matters concerning the representation of defendants and appellants in proceedings;
providing for evidentiary matters in proceedings, including matters relating to the giving of expert evidence;

prescribing the procedure and practice with respect to the delivery of verdicts, the convicting and sentencing of persons found by the Court guilty of offences and the acquittal of persons found by the Court not guilty of offences;
prescribing the procedure for proceedings in the Court under section 126 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 and Part 4 of the Victims Compensation Act 1996;
conferring on the Court the same powers as the Supreme Court has to make an order for a view of real property for the purposes of any proceedings;
subject to the Costs in Criminal Cases Act 1967 , providing for matters relating to the payment of the costs of or in relation to proceedings and, in particular—

empowering the Court to order an Australian legal practitioner appearing in particular proceedings to disclose the amount of any costs that the Australian legal practitioner intends to retain out of any sum ordered by the Court to be paid to the Australian legal practitioner's client; and

empowering the Court to order the Australian legal practitioner for a party to particular proceedings personally to pay specified costs of the proceedings and to order further that the costs so specified not be recoverable by the Australian legal practitioner from the party.

[subs (2) am Act 210 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 238 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 80 of 1993 s 3 and Sch 2 ; Act 120 of 1998 s 3 and Sch 2.13, effective 26 November 1998 ; Act 94 of 1999 s 6 and Sch 4 ; Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 7, effective 6 July 2004; Act 120 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3[3.8] , effective 4 December 2006]
A provision of the rules may—
apply generally or be limited in its application by reference to specified exceptions or factors;
apply differently according to different factors of a specified kind; or
authorise any matter or thing to be from time to time determined, applied or regulated by any specified person or body,
or may do any combination of those things.
[subs (4) rep Act 86 of 1997 s 5 and Sch 3]

Despite any other provision of this Act, the provisions of Part 3 of Chapter 4 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 and any rules under that Part apply to proceedings in the Court in its criminal jurisdiction.
[subs (5) insrt Act 107 of 2006 Sch 1.13[2], effective 29 November 2006]
[s 171A rep Act 48 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 32]
[s 171B rep Act 48 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 32]
[s 171C rep Act 48 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 32]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 171D] s 171D Practice and procedure of Supreme Court to be followed unless other provision made

leg:heading.title: Practice and procedure of Supreme Court to be followed unless other provision made

p.text: Subject to this Act and the rules, the procedure and practice of the District Court when exercising its criminal jurisdiction shall, so far as practicable, be the same as the procedure and practice of the Supreme Court when exercising similar jurisdiction.
[s 171D insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 4]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 171D.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 171D.

The Supreme Court of New South Wales has the power to issue a bench warrant to bring a person against whom a periodic detention order has been made before the court so that the person can be dealt with. Consequently, the District Court has a similar power pursuant to s 171D : R v Webster (1998) 43 NSWLR 256 .
[s 172 rep Act 210 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 173] s 173 Directions as to sittings of Court in its criminal jurisdiction

leg:heading.title: Directions as to sittings of Court in its criminal jurisdiction

p.text: The Chief Judge is, by order in writing, to direct that the Court is, during a specified calendar year, to sit in its criminal jurisdiction at such proclaimed places or other places within the State and at such times as may be specified in the order.

The Chief Judge is to consult with the Attorney General before making a direction under subsection (1) that substantially alters the frequency of sittings at a particular place compared with the previous calendar year.
[subs (1A) insrt Act 107 of 2006 Sch 1.13[3], effective 29 November 2006]

If a place specified in a direction under subsection (1) is not a proclaimed place, the specified place is, for the purposes of this Act or any other law and while the direction remains in force, taken to form part of the nearest proclaimed place to the specified place.
Subsection (2) ceases to have effect if and when the specified place becomes a proclaimed place.

A direction under subsection (1) may be given in respect of a particular calendar year before the commencement of that year or, in respect of the remaining portion of that year, after the commencement of that year.
[s 173 subst Act 71 of 2003 s 3 and Sch 3, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 174] s 174 General provisions as to sittings

p.text: Subject to this Part—
the Court may sit simultaneously at different sitting places in its criminal jurisdiction;
a Judge shall preside at such sittings of the Court in its criminal jurisdiction at such sitting places as the Chief Judge may from time to time direct; and
two or more Judges may preside simultaneously at separate sittings of the Court in its criminal jurisdiction at the one sitting place.
[subs (1) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 4 ; Act 210 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 71 of 2003 s 3 and Sch 3, effective 1 January 2004]

Where a sitting of the Court in its criminal jurisdiction is to be held and the Judge who is to preside at that sitting is not present at the time appointed for the sitting to commence, a registrar may adjourn the sitting to another time.
[subs (2) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 4 ; Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003]
An appeal to the Court in its criminal jurisdiction may be heard and disposed of by the Court sitting at any sitting place.
[subs (1) am Act 71 of 2003 s 3 and Sch 3, effective 1 January 2004]
Subsection (1) has effect subject to any other Act or any instrument under any other Act.
[s 175 subst Act 210 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 176] s 176 No proceedings in the nature of certiorari

leg:heading.title: No proceedings in the nature of certiorari

p.text: No adjudication on appeal of the District Court is to be removed by any order into the Supreme Court.
[s 176 insrt Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 176.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 176.

DCA s 176 is a form of privative clause that excludes the availability of relief in the nature of certiorari based on error of law on the face of the record. It does not preclude relief for jurisdictional error: see Downey v Acting District Court Judge Boulton (No 5) (2010) 78 NSWLR 499; 272 ALR 705; [2010] NSWCA 240; BC201006774 at [133]–[134] ; Garde v Dowd (2011) 80 NSWLR 620; [2011] NSWCA 115; BC201103235 at [10] ; Elias v DPP [2012] NSWCA 302; BC201207370 at [5] ; Spanos v Lazaris [2008] NSWCA 74; BC200802890 at [15] per Basten JA (Beazley and Bell JJA agreeing); Director of Public Prosecutions v Emanuel (2009) 193 A Crim R 552; [2009] NSWCA 42; BC200901816 at [18] (Spigelman CJ) and [45] (Basten JA); Hoffenberg v District Court of New South Wales [2010] NSWCA 142; BC201006394 at [3]–[5] per Basten JA; Kirk v Industrial Relations Commission (NSW) (2010) 239 CLR 531; 262 ALR 569; [2010] HCA 1; BC201000230 at [100] .

A failure to accord procedural fairness, and ostensible or apprehended bias, may involve jurisdictional error: Kirk v Industrial Relations Commission (NSW) (2010) 239 CLR 531; 262 ALR 569; [2010] HCA 1; BC201000230 at [60] ; see also Re Refugee Review Tribunal; Ex parte HB (2001) 179 ALR 513; [2001] HCA 34; BC200102953 at [10] .
